entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 19 at 2:33PM MDT until August 19 at 5:45PM MDT by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of east central Idaho, including the following county, Lemhi.
This includes the following Specific Areas... Salmon River Road near Moose Fire Burn Area.
* WHEN...Until 545 PM MDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 233 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Overflowing poor drainage areas will cause minor flooding in the advisory area. Between 0.4 and 0.6 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.3 to 0.5 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - This includes the following Specific Areas... Salmon River Road near Moose Fire Burn Area. - https://www.weather.gov/mso/hydrology

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 545 PM MDT THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 19 at 2:29PM MDT until August 19 at 4:30PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
At 229 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2.5 and 3.5 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, gulches, roads, and poor drainage and low-lying areas.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Mainly rural areas of Central Elbert County.
This includes the following streams and drainages... East Bijou Creek, Reed Springs Creek and Big Sandy Creek.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 19 at 3:19PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
AQAHGX
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for Tuesday, August 20, 2024.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and surrounding areas on Tuesday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive through lanes, conserving energy and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone: Ozone: The Facts www.tceq.texas.gov/airquality/monops/ozonefacts.html EPA AirNow: www.airnow.gov/?city=Houston&state=TX&country=USA Take Care of Texas: www.takecareoftexas.org/conservation-tips/keep-our-air-clean
entry.cap:areaDesc: Inland Harris; Inland Brazoria; Inland Galveston; Coastal Harris; Coastal Brazoria; Coastal Galveston; Brazoria Islands; Galveston Island; Bolivar Peninsula

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 19 at 3:04PM EDT until August 19 at 6:15PM EDT by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary:
FFWALY
The National Weather Service in Albany has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Northeastern Albany County in east central New York... Southeastern Schenectady County in east central New York...
* Until 615 PM EDT.
* At 304 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 0.5 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1.5 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar and automated gauges.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 19 at 12:08PM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
The following message is transmitted on behalf of the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division, and the Wyoming Department of Health.
* WHAT...Air Quality Alert for Wildfire Smoke.
* WHERE...The Wind River Basin and portions of the Tetons and Wind River Mountains.
* WHEN...11 AM MDT Monday through 1 PM MDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Smoke from the Fish Creek Fire near Togwotee Pass will limit visibility and lead to poor air quality.
HEALTH INFORMATION...The Wyoming Department of Health recommends that the elderly, young children, and individuals with respiratory problems avoid excessive physical exertion and minimize outdoor activities during this time. Wildfire smoke is made up of a variety of pollutants, including particulate matter and ozone, which can cause respiratory health effects. Although these people are most susceptible to health impacts, the Department of Health also advises that everyone should avoid prolonged exposure to poor air quality conditions.
CURRENT CONDITIONS...The Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, Air Quality Division offers near real-time air quality data for Wyoming's monitoring stations and health effects information to help the public interpret current conditions. Current air quality conditions across the state of Wyoming can be found at http://www.wyvisnet.com/.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Teton and Gros Ventre Mountains; Wind River Mountains East; Upper Wind River Basin; Wind River Basin; Lander Foothills

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 PM MDT TUESDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 19 at 1:05PM EDT until August 20 at 1:30PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Madison County Emergency Management continues to report gradually rising water levels in portions of southeastern Madison County east of Lee and areas around US 90 as well as areas south of I 10 east of State Road 53 and the Suwannee River. Water levels remain high in the vicinity of I-10 and exit 262, but flood waters are not impacting access to or travel on Interstate 10. All of the flooding is due to past heavy rainfall from Hurricane Debby. Flood waters are continuing to gradually shift slowly south and east toward the Suwannee River.
* WHERE...A portion of Big Bend Florida, including the following county, Southeastern Madison County.
* WHEN...Until 130 PM EDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is occurring. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1247 PM EDT, Madison County Emergency Management reports continued flooding in the warned area. - Flooding will likely persist through this week as water runoff from Hurricane Debby continues from more than 2 weeks ago. With high groundwater levels, locations near small creeks, springs, or sinks in Southeast Madison County could be prone to flooding on relatively short notice. If you live in an area prone to flooding, take action to protect property. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Lee. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 19 at 6:09AM AKDT until August 19 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by high winds backing up flow along the lower Kuskokwim River and Kuskokwim Delta continues.
* WHERE...Along the Kuskokwim River, related tributaries and low lying areas including: Akiak, Bethel and several other smaller communities downstream to the Delta.
* WHEN...Until 600 PM AKDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Residents reported flooding and rapid bank erosion during Friday and Saturday's high tide at Akiak, Napakiak, Kasigluk, and Tuntutuliak. At Napakiak, residents reported high water threatening community infrastructures, from Friday and Saturday's high tide, inundating most low spots in the village, including the road to the dump. Water levels are reported to be higher than during breakup flooding this past May. Residents in Kasigluk reported water was encroaching on low lying residences, with water levels similar to those seen during this year's breakup. In Tuntutuliak, residents are reporting high water in the village over the past few days.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 553 AM AKDT, water levels are receding, but remain high. Another high tide cycle today could bring water levels as high as seen on Friday and Saturday. Water levels will resume receding tonight. - For Kuskokwim River at Bethel: At 5:00am the stage was 6.35 feet. Flood Stage is 8.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:

.Higher-than-predicted water levels combined with near-peak monthly tides will lead to minor coastal flooding this afternoon. A south swell moving through will increase the flooding potential along south facing shores this afternoon. Water levels will gradually lower Tuesday through the rest of the week.

* WHEN...This afternoon during the peak daily high tide cycle.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of beaches that are normally dry, minor coastal erosion, and saltwater inundation.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 19 at 4:36AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
A band of residual ash from the eruption of Sheveluch on the Kamchatka Peninsula Saturday persists near the eastern Aleutians and Alaska Peninsula this morning. Diminishing winds at the surface and aloft are allowing some of this ash to settle to the surface, resulting in the potential for trace amounts of ash for these locations. Any residual ash is expected to disperse by this afternoon.
People with respiratory ailments in these areas are encouraged to avoid or reduce outdoor activity to avoid inhaling ash.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 19 at 2:44AM AKDT until August 20 at 1:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Central Brooks Range rivers and streams, including the following areas, South Slopes Of The Central Brooks Range and Upper Koyukuk Valley. This includes the cities of Wiseman, Coldfoot, Chandalar Dot Camp, Iniakuk Lake, The Dalton Highway From Mp 165 To Mp 232, Allakaket, Bettles, Evansville, Alatna, Gobblers Knob, Prospect Creek, Finger Mountain, The Yukon River Bridge, And The Dalton Highway From Mp 39 To Mp 164.
* WHEN...Through Tuesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - 2-3 inches of rain over past two days along with another 1-2 inches during the next 12 hours will cause rapid increases in stream levels. Tributaries to the Koyukuk River could reach bankfull levels by Sunday evening or Monday morning.
The Koyukuk River at Bettles and Allakaket will rise significantly over the next 24 hours and crest late Monday or Tuesday. River levels at Bettles and Allakaket are currently forecast to remain below flood stage. The Koyukuk River at Hughes is expected to crest Wednesday below flood stage.
IMPACTS: Expect rapid water level increases over next 24 hours on rivers and streams in the Koyukuk River basin. Minor overbank flooding of some Koyukuk River tributaries is possible.
- Http://www.weather.gov/aprfc
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Slopes Of The Central Brooks Range; Upper Koyukuk Valley; Dalton Highway Summits

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued August 19 at 3:31AM EDT until August 19 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 5 to 8 feet in the surf zone. For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...East Carteret County, and Ocracoke Island and Hatteras Island.
* WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Monday evening. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 10 AM EDT Monday. For the High Surf Advisory, until 10 AM EDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways resulting in a low threat of property damage. Some roads and low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes adjacent to the waterfront may experience shallow flooding. Vulnerable dune structures along Ocracoke and Hatteras Islands will be most susceptible to impacts from ocean overwash. Portions of NC-12 may be impacted, especially around times of high tide. The next high tide is around 8 AM Monday morning. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion expected. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 1:30 PM this afternoon.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Carteret; Ocracoke Island; Hatteras Island

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 19 at 2:07AM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
The combination of hot temperatures and elevated relative humidity values will result in widespread moderate heat risk across Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley today. Heat index values are expected to range between 105 and 115 degrees this afternoon into early evening. Isolated areas may experience heat indices between 111 and 115 degrees for a short period of time.
If working outside today, be sure to drink plenty of water, wear loose-fitting and light-colored clothing, and take frequent breaks in air-conditioned locations. Be sure to check on elderly and infirm neighbors and relatives, provide shade and fresh water for outdoor pets and livestock, and check the backseat of your vehicle when transporting children.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Zapata; Jim Hogg; Brooks; Inland Kenedy; Starr; Southern Hidalgo; Inland Willacy; Inland Cameron; Coastal Kenedy; Northern Hidalgo; Coastal Willacy; Coastal Cameron

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 18 at 6:02PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
AQAFWD
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Dallas-Fort Worth area for Monday, August 19, 2024.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone air pollution in the Dallas-Fort Worth area on Monday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive-through lanes, conserving energy, and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone:
Ozone: The Facts (www.tceq.texas.gov/goto/ozonefacts)
Air North Texas: (www.airnorthtexas.org)
EPA Air Now (www.airnow.gov/index.cfm?action.local_state&STATEID=45&TAB=0)
Take care of Texas (www.takecareoftexas.org)
North Central Texas Council of Governments Air Quality (www.nctcog.org/trans/air/index.asp)
entry.cap:areaDesc: Wise; Denton; Collin; Hunt; Parker; Tarrant; Dallas; Rockwall; Kaufman; Hood; Johnson; Ellis; Henderson

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 18 at 3:21PM EDT until August 20 at 11:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall last week and elevated tides.
* WHERE...A portion of northeast South Carolina, including the following county, Horry.
* WHEN...Until 1100 AM EDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...At 17 feet...flooding of about three dozen ground level structures on Rosewood Drive, Star Creek Circle, and Recreation Road worsens and about 24 more ground level structures begin to flood. Flooding expands on Rosewood Drive, River Road, Ed Smith Avenue, Creekside Drive, Mill Creek Road, Smith Boulevard, Folly Lane, John Henry Lane, Star Creek Circle, West Oak Circle and Roberta Lane with residences isolated. Zeddie Lane, Renata Lane, and Earls Road begin to flood. Lowest yards along Shem Creek Circle begin to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 305 PM EDT, Heavy rainfall from last week, and elevated tides will continue to create issues along the Waterway near Socastee.
The Waterway at Socastee is forecast to peak to 16.5 to 16.7 feet tonight into Monday. The water levels are not expected to fall below 15 ft until late next weekend. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Socastee. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Socastee. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 10:53AM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Quality Advisory...IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM PDT MONDAY.
A Smoke Air Quality Advisory has been issued. Wildfires burning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will cause air quality to reach unhealthy levels.
Pollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes...runny nose...aggravate heart and lung diseases...and aggravate other serious health problems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it is smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung condition.
For additional information...please visit the Web site at http://www.oregon.gov/DEQ

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM PDT MONDAY
